text: <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - mediated cell cycle progression and inhibition of apoptosis does not require NF-kappa B or activating protein - 1 activation in primary human T cells .
The <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> growth hormone is the major growth factor of activated T lymphocytes during a developing immune response .
<extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is required not only for cell cycle progression but also to protect Ag - activated T cells from programmed cell death .
In several cell types , activation of NF-kappa B and / or activating protein - 1 ( AP-1 ) has been demonstrated to be extremely important in blocking apoptosis .

To determine whether either or both of these transcription factors are involved in cell survival or cell cycle progression in response to <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , primary human T cells responsive to the growth factor were analyzed for NF-kappa B and AP-1 activation .

The current study clearly demonstrates that <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> does not induce <extra_id_0> I kappa B alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> degradation or NF-kappa B activation in primary human T cells that respond to <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> by entering the cell cycle and avoiding apoptosis .

text: Similarly , <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> neither activates JNK nor increases AP-1 binding activity to a consensus o-tetradecanoylphorbol 13-acetate ( TPA ) response element .
On the other hand , the growth factor does induce the activation of <extra_id_0> STAT3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and STAT5 in these cells , as has been previously demonstrated .

These data show that neither NF-kappa B nor AP-1 activation is required for <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - mediated survival or cell cycle progression in activated primary human T cells .
